abstract: The Upshot; Tyler Cowen Economic View column examines research on so-called 'sharing economy,' citing evidence that Uber drivers earn more than traditional taxi drivers and that Airbnb rentals are subsidizing middle-class incomes; observes that while efficiencies of sector are robust, emerging roles are disproportionately going to those with college degrees, depriving less-educated workers of some traditional jobs.
lead_paragraph: Working for sharing-economy services can benefit ambitious, educated self-starters, but stifle those who are less adaptable or have less schooling.

headline.main: In an Uber World, Fortune Favors the Freelancer
headline.print_headline: In an Uber World, Fortune Favors the Freelancer

snippet: Working for sharing-economy services can benefit ambitious, educated self-starters, but stifle those who are less adaptable or have less schooling.
